subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit 4.11-beta-1 is released
msgSnippet: Hello, any improvements in hamcrest are now used for junit as well - as are all new bugs :-). There is no easy answer, I guess. As
messageBody:
Hello,

any improvements in hamcrest are now used for junit as well - as are
all new bugs :-). There is no easy answer, I guess. As
org.junit.Assert.<T>assertThat(T,org.hamcrest.Matcher<? super T>):void
exists, an alternative approach to use shaded versions of the hamcrest
will not work. So this should be JUnit5 :-).

Regards Mirko


On Thu, Oct 18, 2012 at 4:20 PM, Paul Holser <pholser@...> wrote:
> Marc, I think the way it's set up for non-Maven users is fine; as a Maven user, I'll be thrilled to depend explicitly only on junit:junit.
>
> Ultimately I think it'd be great to break JUnit's dependency on Hamcrest entirely, but I suspect that's a much more involved effort (JUnit 5?).
>
> Thanks again!
>
> --p
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Marc Philipp <mphilipp82@...> wrote:
>>
>> Paul,
>>
>> we have deprecated the Maven artifact that used to have Hamcrest embedded since that didn't make any sense from a Maven point-of-view (see the release notes for details).
>>
>> The all-in-one JAR (junit.jar) is still offered as a download for users that simply want to get started using JUnit without having to download an extra JAR from Hamcrest.
>>
>> An alternative would be to remove the two JARs from the downloads altogether and instead put the Hamcrest JAR along with what is now called junit-dep.jar inside the JUnit ZIP file with a simple README that explains how to use it. In this scenario, there wouldn't be an old school junit.jar any longer.
>>
>> What do you think?
>>
>> Regards, Marc
>>
